bwwExcerpt: When songs provide so little information, barely differentiating the characters let alone advancing the plot, a musical tends to sag. And when a musical has gone to some trouble to accommodate those songs — the movie of “The Notebook” runs two hours, the show hardly 20 minutes more — the trade-offs are of the nose-versus-face variety.
showScoreExcerpt: "Love is powerful. Dementia is sad. The result can be heartbreaking."

the trade-offs are of the nose-versus-face variety

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The critic identifies fundamental structural flaws in the musical's songs and book, using the harsh metaphor of self-defeating 'nose-versus-face' trade-offs, with only minimal acknowledgment of emotional impact. | GPT-4o-mini: The review expresses significant criticism of the musical's songs and their impact on the storytelling, leading to a clear negative recommendation.
